item.title: Amar Bose on problem solving
item.description: Last few days I have been listening to the late great Amar Bose on general problem solving. In one video he recounts Professor Chu’s working relationship with General Dynamics. Chu would have engineers lined up outside his room for months in advance. They would only get 10 minutes with him but always came out of the room relieved. Clearly Amar wanted to figure out what went on in that room so he asked Chu.

item.title: Applying the antifragile framework to a career in energy
item.description:
Sometimes I find it useful to adopt an entirely different mental model than what I normally do.

My question is:

Suppose you have decent physics skills, how do you apply them to solve problems in the energy sector?

My knee-jerk answer without thinking would be, go nuclear. It’s the safest reliable energy source, and depending on the rationality of european governments and our ability to de-criminalize nuclear, will be the dominant future energy stack. So it sort of makes sense to learn everything about nuclear science and engineering. Right?

item.title: The Genus of Angular Momentum
item.description:
What is the genus of angular momentum?

We want a definition on the form of:

Angular momentum is a X with the differentia Y.

But it is not self-evident to me what exactly it should be.

We know that it is a physical quantity, but this might be too wide of a category.

Suggestion 1: Angular momentum is a physical quantity that describes rotational motion.

This can’t be proper since, e.g., define $L = r \times v$, and that would also describe rotational motion but not be angular momentum. So the definition is missing an inertial quantity.

item.title: §115 charge density
item.description:
This section deals with the derivation of the current density for charges particles in a magnetic field.

Why do we begin with:

$$ \delta H = -(1/c) \int \vec{j} \cdot \vec{A} dV \ ? $$

Because the Lagrangian for a charged particle in a magnetic field is $L = \frac{1}{2}m\dot{x}^2 + q \dot{x} \cdot A - q \phi$.

Why does the Lagrangian look like that? What is the perceptual base of this expression?

item.title: Realism and The Aim of Science - Preface 1956
item.description:
The following is an expedition to the preface to Karl Popper’s Realism and The Aim of Science. The preface deals with “the non-existence of scientific method.” It is just so surprising and as in many cases with post Kantians, way worse than one can first imagine since you can’t read a single page without your head exploding with questions.

The preface starts out with:

As a rule, I begin my lectures on Scientific Method by telling my students that scientific method does not exist.

item.title: Landau - Mechanics Vol 1 - Problem 3
item.description:
Since I got this problem wrong I thought it would be necessary to write about it for my own sake.

“A simple pendulum of mass $m$ whose point of support moves uniformly on a vertical circle with constant frequency $\gamma$. Find the Lagrangian for the system when placed in a uniform gravitational field (acceleration g).”

First of all, what is meant by “vertical circle”? A “vertical circle” is a circle that lies in the plane, where the motion is perpendicular to the ground. Contrast this with a horizontal circle, where instead the motion would be parallell to the ground.

item.title: Thales to Dewey - Application to St. Augustine
item.description:
“Do you know that you exist? If he so much hears the question there can be no doubt about the answer.”

What can we learn from St. Augustine?

Reason

The first good thing about Augustine is that he was not a skeptic, i.e., he defended the possibility of knowledge. But what surprised me was that he did not do it solely on logical grounds but on moral ones. What does that mean? For Augustine, “happiness” seems to be the goal, and since the skeptic by his own construction is someone who searches without any possibility of discovery, he cannot be happy. In fact, we would say that he is rather silly. In other words, the skeptic sets himself up for inevitable failure since his tool of survival (reason) leads nowhere.

item.title: Mobiustransformations in Hamiltonian Mechanics
item.description:
At a lecture on Hamliton-Jacobi method for solving EOM, specifically where there is some periodic motion and we want to flatten it to a constant horizontal line in phase space, I wondered if we equivalently could do it with a tool from complex analysis.

Phase space is equipped with a symplectic 2-form $\omega = dq \wedge dp$ which has to be preserved if we want a valid canonical transformation. So the question naturally arises, under what conditions do Mobius transforms preserve this symplectic structure if at all?
